title: 108_hr5375
content: The Act may be cited as the "United Nations Accountability Act of 2004". The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption. OIOS audits revealed mismanagement in the contract for independent inspection agents in Iraq. The United Nations Oil-for-Food program faced allegations of mismanagement, fraud, and corruption. OIOS audits revealed that the United Nations had not fully performed its contractual duties. The audit found that the contractor failed to maintain required staffing levels, overcharged the United Nations, engaged in unprofessional conduct, and reported inaccurate figures for goods. The United Nations Office of Iraq Programs was criticized by the OIOS for poor contract management, lack of designated contract manager, and uncertainty about services provided. The United Nations policy is to not release OIOS audit reports to member states, and the United States was denied access. The United Nations has denied the United States access to OIOS audits of the Oil-for-Food Program, undermining member states' ability to fulfill their responsibilities in connection with UN programs. SEC. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY AND TRANSPARENCY MEASURES FOR THE UNITED NATIONS. Congress urges the President to ensure that all OIOS audit reports are shared with UN member states promptly and without modifications, except to protect privacy rights. The Department of State must report on UN officials' financial disclosure requirements within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The Department of State must assess financial disclosure rules for United Nations officials and recommend reforms to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines the terms "oil-for-food program" and "Office of Internal Oversight Services" in relation to United Nations resolutions. The curr_chunk discusses the role of the Office of Internal Oversight Services in monitoring program implementation and conducting management audits. The term "appropriate congressional committees" is defined as specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate.
